29:10 Yess!! Venus FTW!! I soo wish that a larger number super compact armored camera ball capsules would be dropped there very soon.
High numbers of cheap mass produced units could maybe make up for lack in durability and motility since that's hard (for known reasons). Smaller means way easier to armor.
But I bet that a relatively simple system with one or more floats (metal ball bladders) tethered to a ground scraping anchor (hard, durable and solid metal ball?) could scrape up more than enough energy from wind gradients, thermal gradients, and ground drag friction (with plenty of margin) to actively cool a tiny well isolated capsule (mounted somewhere in the middle) that just holds a few very small cameras and minimal electronics for processing and data transmission. This way mission time could be extended from a mere few minutes to orders of magnitude more. We need high-res pictures of diverse spots of the ground from the perspective of the ground (ideally somehow human eye level - fixed on that hypothetical tether at that height - if that works). Venusian ground on smaller scales is still a very big mystery, beside the view samples of low-res glimpses that Venera gave (which where an incredible feat at that time) we have absolutely nothing. Which is embarrassing when compared to the images we have from mars and asteroids. It's about high time. And it could be done super quickly compared to missions to the gas giants.

Inconel, and all the nickel super alloys, are really good with corrosion and heat resistance, while maintaining really good physical properties, and have a good strength to weight ratio. But clearly Beck and anyone who's done a touch of metallurgy knows, that if it wasn't for the shear mass, you'd pick refractory metals instead. All things are compromises. Inconel is generally a good one (if you ignore the price). Molybdenum or tungsten are good if you ignore that they'd make your rocket too heavy to take off. Tungsten is a good example. It's melting point is about as good as it gets. It barely melts at "surface of sun" type temperatures. But it's one of the few elements with densities up there with uranium. It's absurdly heavy. But it's relatively cheap. It's not cheap to shape, because it's also very hard. But the purchase price is not absurd, as its fairly abundant.

So cool What if we combined Electron rockets, microwave transmission and super conductivity.  The fuel tanks on rockets are cold and a thin supper conductive grid might allow microwave beams to simultaneously beam power to the rocket as it is taking off, for its pressure pumps.  On existing commercial supper conductors, steel is the backing surface, and acts as an insulator.  Graphene with copper imperfections that are supper conductive could simply be taped on the tank sections to form a simple hashed grid.  Would this work?  Would the superconductivity of a microwave receiver help?   If it is not needed would the beam from Microwaves allow Electron Rockets to not need a large store of heavy batteries?

To strike that perfect balance, you need resources. For big projects like SLS (analysis) and Starship (innovation), resource utilization in terms of construction is high, for Rocket Lab's smaller and cheaper rockets it's low because of material strength to size ratio is in favor of smaller rockets. So it's easier to strike a better balance when it's cheaper to innovate and not have to refly until later to fully verify. Rocket Lab nonetheless is making excellent progress, wish them luck and success!
